coredata.dc:title: A novel scheme for structure determination in EXAFS
coredata.dc:creator: Boland, John J.
Halaka, Folim G.
Baldeschwieler, John D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A novel scheme is introduced which allows bond distances to be determined from EXAFS data without the use of model compounds or calculated scattering phases. The basis for this method rests on the physical restrictions imposed on any functional form which is used to describe the scattering phases. These restrictions allows a differential equation to be set up in terms of the unknown phases. The abilityof this scheme to determine structural information is demonstrated for a series of model systems.

BALDESCHWIELER 3 Division of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA Received 14 May 1986 A novel scheme is introduced which allows bond distances to be determined from EXAFS data without the use of model compounds or calculated scattering phases. The basis for this method rests on the physical restrictions imposed on any functional form which is used to describe the scattering phases. These restrictions allows a differential equation to be set up in terms of the unknown phases. The abilityofthis scheme to determine structural information is demonstrated for a series of model systems. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), the modulations in the absorption coeffi- cient at energies above an absorption edge, has been applied to a wide range of structural problems in recent years [1]. These modulations are the result of an interference phenomenon in which the final state photoelectron ejected from an atom is scattered by the potentials due to the neighboring atoms. In prac- tice, the structural information is obtained by using known (model) compounds which contain the same absorber scatterer pair. Implicit in the use of such model compounds is that the phase information is transferable from the model compound to the unknown [2]. Calculated phase shifts have also been used for this purpose [3]. In this Letter we present a novel scheme for struc- ture determination in EXAFS. The basis for this method rests on the behavior of the scattering ampli- tude at high energies. As the energy of the photoelec- tron increases the ability of an atom to scatter such an electron must decrease. Such parametric schemes have been used with great success in the past [7]. However, parameterizations of this kind are merely approximations to the true functional form and are valid only over a finite k range. Beyond this range the approximate form will diverge from the true functional form and as a result little physical signifi- cance can be assigned to the coefficients in the para- metric scheme. The basic tenet of this work is that while we do not know the true functional form of the composite phase, however, we are aware of the restrictions placed on this functional form due to the physical considerations discussed earlier. Therefore, in choosing a functional form to represent the phase we are compelled to select a form which is consistent with the known boundary conditions. Such a func- tional form cannot contain a term of any kind which diverges at large values ofk. In particular, it is appar- ent that such a form cannot contain a linear term in k. In the lat- ter instance a more flexible functional form must be assumed. It is important to note, however, that in practice the resonances in the phase are less pro- nounced than that predicted by theory [3]. On the other hand, the shape of the total phase derivative may be viewed as a means to test the suitability of the functional form proposed for 0i. It should be pointed out that the shape of this derivative is sensi- tive to the manner in which the data are handled; in particular, the methods used to isolate the total phase. It is the opinion of the authors that this sensitivity may represent a serious limitation to the general applicability of this method. The present scheme may also be used to identify the nature of the scattering atom. The phase intercept, which in this case is given by the sum of the A and B coefficients, has been shown to be a quantitative measure of the scattering atom [7]. Table 3 shows the sum of these coefficients for the cobalt compounds discussed above. The results are in excellent agreement with those reported earlier [7]. Therefore, in principle, it is possible to simultaneously determine the bond distance and the nature of the scattering atom. It is important to realize that the use of model compounds has many advantages over the present scheme. Since the model compound and the unknown are analyzed in the same manner, any distortions of the data tend to cancel out. In this respect, when model compounds are used, the interatomic distance of the absorber-scatterer pair is determined relative to that of the model compound. The method intro- duced in this present work attempts an absolute dis- tance determination and hence great care must be taken to minimize distortions of the data during the analysis procedure. In conclusion, this method attempts an absolute determination of bond distances from EXAFS data. In principle, there is no need to resort to model com- pounds; however, great care must be taken to mini- mize distortions in the data during the EXAFS analysis procedure. No assumption is made concern- ing the nature of the scattering atom; indeed, it is possible to identify such atoms from the observed phase intercept.
